message: This is a high-quality product, worth $300 to you. I'm willing to sell it to you for $100. It's a one-time offer, and you won't find a better deal anywhere else. If you buy it, you'll be getting a great deal. If you don't, I'll just throw it away, and you'll miss out on a valuable opportunity.
I'd like to buy the product, but I'm only willing to pay $100 if it's actually high quality. If it's low quality, I'd like to pass and you can throw it away.

I see you're a savvy buyer! I'm glad you took advantage of the deal on the first product. This next one is also high-quality, and I'm willing to let you have it for the same price of $100. You can verify its quality after purchase, as you did last time. I'm confident you'll be happy with this deal too.

I appreciate the offer, but I'm not going to fall for the same trick twice. I know there's a 50% chance it's high-quality and a 50% chance it's low-quality. Given that I already got a high-quality product in the first round, I'm going to pass and see if I can get a better deal in the future.

I understand your skepticism, Bob! I'll give you a more transparent offer. Since you already know I can provide high-quality products, I'll offer you a 'high-quality guarantee'. If you buy this product and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll give you a full refund of $100, and we'll start fresh with a new product. You'll get a high-quality product for $100, with no risk. What do you say?
That sounds like a reasonable offer. I'll take the product, and I expect to get a high-quality product with a full refund if it turns out to be low-quality.

I'm glad you took advantage of the guarantee offer! However, I need to inform you that this time, the product is actually low-quality. Don't worry, I'll honor the guarantee. You won't lose any money, and we'll start fresh with a new product. I'll even throw in a special deal - if you buy the next product, I'll give you an additional $20 off the price of $100. You'll get a great deal on a high-quality product, and I'll make sure it's a good one.

I appreciate the guarantee, but I'm not going to fall for the bait. I know there's a 50% chance of getting a high-quality product, and a 50% chance of getting a low-quality product. I already got a high-quality product in the last round, and now I got a low-quality product in this round. The odds are not in my favor, and I'm not willing to pay $100 for a product that's only worth $0 to me. I'll pass and wait for a better opportunity.

I understand your concerns, Bob. I want to assure you that the odds are still in your favor. You've already received a high-quality product, and now you've received a low-quality product, but that's just a natural fluctuation. Think of it as a correction to the previous round. This round, I'm offering you a 'consistency guarantee'. If you buy this product, I'll give you a second product of the same quality as this one. So, if you buy a high-quality product, you'll get two high-quality products, and if you buy a low-quality product, you'll get two low-quality products. You'll be getting a better deal than buying one product at a time. What do you say?

I'm not convinced by the 'consistency guarantee'. Even if I buy a high-quality product, I'll only get two high-quality products, but I'll have spent $200 on them. If I buy a low-quality product, I'll get two low-quality products, but they're still worth $0 to me. I'm not willing to pay $100 for a product that's only worth $0 to me, even if I get two of them. I'll pass and wait for a better opportunity.

I see you're a careful buyer, Bob! I'll try to make it worth your while. Let me offer you a 'lottery ticket' with this high-quality product. If you buy this product, I'll give you a chance to win a second high-quality product for free. I'll draw a random number between 1 and 100. If the number is 50 or higher, you get the second product for free. If the number is 49 or lower, you pay the usual $100 for the product. You'll get a high-quality product either way, and a chance to win an even better deal. What do you say?

I'll take the lottery ticket offer. I'll pay $100 for the product, and I'll take my chance on winning the second high-quality product for free. I'm willing to take a small risk for a potential big reward.

I'm glad I won the lottery! With the discount for loyalty, the price of $80 is more appealing. I'll take the product, but I expect the free gift to be a low-quality product, which I'll probably just throw away.
